conclusion: Analyze the behavior of particles as they pass through the velocity selector N.
The velocity selector consists of a uniform electric field E and a uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to each other.
Electric force must balance the magnetic force for a particle to pass through the velocity selector along a straight line.
Electric force on a charged particle is given by F_E = qE.
Magnetic force on a charged particle is given by F_B = qvB.
For the particle to pass through the velocity selector along a straight line, qE = qvB, hence E = vB.
This condition ensures that the particle moves with a constant velocity v through the velocity selector.
The first particle has a mass m and charge q, and it passes through the velocity selector with a velocity v.
The second particle has a mass 2m and charge q, and it also passes through the velocity selector with a velocity v.
The second particle departs from the velocity selector with a deviation d from the dashed line, indicating it experiences a force due to the magnetic field.
The radius R of the circular path of a charged particle in a magnetic field is given by R = mv/qB.
For the second particle with mass 2m, R_2 = 2R.
The deviation d is half the diameter of the circle, so d = R_2 = 2R.
The radius R for the first particle is R = d/2.
The kinetic energy E_k of a particle is given by E_k = 1/2 mv^2.
The particle passes through the velocity selector with a velocity v such that v = qE/B.
Substituting v into the kinetic energy formula gives E_k = 1/2 m (qE/B)^2.
Substitute E = vB back into the equation to get E_k = 1/2 m q^2 v^2.
The kinetic energy of the second particle when it leaves the velocity selector is 1/2 m q^2 v^2.
